Based on my search results, I found several fascinating hidden secrets and lesser-known facts about Jane Eyre and Charlotte Brontë's writing process. Here are the most intriguing discoveries:

## Hidden Secrets and Lesser-Known Facts about Jane Eyre

### The Mysterious Writing Process

Few people know how quickly Brontë composed Jane Eyre. Nor do many know that she wrote it during a devastating and anxious period in her life. Thwarted in her passionate, secret, and forbidden love for a married man, she found herself living in a home suddenly imperiled by the fact that her father, a minister, the sole support of the family, was on the brink of blindness.(no content)After his hasty operation, as she nursed him in an isolated apartment kept dark to help him heal his eyes, Brontë began writing Jane Eyre - literally writing her masterpiece in darkness while caring for her father.

### Concealment and Secrecy

Why did Charlotte Brontë go to such great lengths on the publication of her acclaimed, best-selling novel, Jane Eyre, to conceal its authorship from her family, close friends, and the press? In The Secret History of Jane Eyre, John Pfordresher tells the enthralling story of Brontë's compulsion to write her masterpiece and why she then turned around and vehemently disavowed it.

### The Family Name Secret

Did you know that Brontë is not really the family's original inherited surname? Charlotte's father, Patrick Brontë was born Patrick Brunty to a large, poor family in Ireland. He sought to distance himself from his Irish roots by changing 'Brunty' to 'Brontë,' the Latin spelling which means thunder.

### Publication Mysteries

Jane Eyre was originally published in 1847 as an "autobiography" of Jane Eyre herself, edited by Currer Bell. This created additional layers of mystery about the true author. Charlotte Brontë's name — she, Emily, and Anne each took on male pseudonyms when publishing their work. They called themselves Currer, Ellis, and Acton Bell respectively, and used these names to avoid the stigma of being a woman in the literary world.

### Autobiographical Elements Hidden in Plain Sight

Jane Eyre, like Charlotte, was also poor and motherless. In fact, every single one of the heroines in Charlotte Brontë's novels, from Frances Henri in The Professor, to the schoolgirl in her last unfinished work Emma, are motherless.

The early sequences, in which Jane is sent to Lowood, a harsh boarding school, are derived from the author's own experiences. Helen Burns's death from tuberculosis (referred to as consumption) recalls the deaths of Charlotte Brontë's sisters, Elizabeth and Maria, who died of the disease in childhood as a result of the conditions at their school.

### Hidden Inspirations for Gothic Elements

The Gothic manor of Thornfield Hall was probably inspired by North Lees Hall, near Hathersage in the Peak District in Derbyshire. This was visited by Charlotte Brontë and her friend Ellen Nussey in the summer of 1845, and is described by the latter in a letter dated 22 July 1845. It was the residence of the Eyre family, and its first owner, Agnes Ashurst, was reputedly confined as a lunatic in a padded second floor room.

### Early Writing Experiments

The sequence in which Mr Rochester's wife sets fire to the bed curtains was prepared in an August 1830 homemade publication of Brontë's The Young Men's Mag - showing that key dramatic scenes were conceived years before the novel was written.

### Location Mysteries

Charlotte Brontë began composing Jane Eyre in Manchester, and she likely envisioned Manchester Cathedral churchyard as the burial place for Jane's parents and Manchester as the birthplace of Jane herself.

These discoveries reveal that Jane Eyre was far more autobiographical and secretive in its creation than many readers realize, written during a period of personal crisis and concealment that Charlotte Brontë went to great lengths to hide from the world.
